breakfast1.description: Lucie, for once, is having an uninterrupted breakfast.  Felix is still sleeping.  What about Milo?
breakfast1.title: Breakfast 1

breakfast3.description: He doesn't mind being left alone as long as it's to do something dangerous.
breakfast3.title: Breakfast 3

breakfast5.description: Once you've figured out how to climb, why stop halfway?
breakfast5.title: Breakfast 5

brothers1.description: Felix and Milo often lust after the same toy at the same time.
brothers1.title: Brothers 1

playhouse1.description: Our first attempt at building this playhouse was a comedy of errors: it collapsed into bits of wood trying to get the roof together. This time Austin came the rescue. He brought his tools and his mad carpentry skillz.
playhouse1.title: Playhouse 1

playhouse2.description: How many adults does it take to build a simple kid's playhouse?  Three:  one to entertain Felix, one to keep Milo at bay, and one to do everything else.
playhouse2.title: Playhouse 2

playhouse3.description: Felix immediately set up ice cream shop. What flavor do you want?
playhouse3.title: Playhouse 3

shave.description: A morning ritual:  chewing on the electric shaver while Dean shaves.  The vibrations must feel good on his gums.
shave.title: Shave

tent1.description: This little tent, a hand-me-down from the Joyces, has seen a lot of action from both boys.
tent1.title: Tent 1

tent2.description: The problem with crawling?   No free hands.  Thank goodness for the mouth.
tent2.title: Tent 2

zoo1.description: Milo is fascinated by any pigeon, cat or dog he meets. So we took him to the zoo. The giraffes were okay but not as cool as the neighbor's cat.
zoo1.title: Zoo 1

zoo3.description: The fearsome beast knows how to make its kill:  go directly for the sun-regulation device.
zoo3.title: Zoo 3

zoo4.description: His prey will roast nicely in the sun.
zoo4.title: Zoo 4

description:
New baby signs this week:
  • [waving]: bye bye. Every baby and adult uses this sign. Milo had waved before, but now he truly gets it and waves bye bye appropriately.
  • [fingers in mouth]: drink. Sometimes during meals he puts his fingers in his mouth. We are still not sure whether he is asking for a drink, or complaining about teething pain.
When Lucie talks in French to Felix, he is likely to re-use the same French words she just did. However, the grammar is all English.

Lucie: Est-ce que le chien a abboyé toute la nuit? (did the dog bark all night?)
Felix: No, the chien did not abboyé all nuit.

Lucie: Je ne sais pas. (I don't know)
Felix: I sais pas either.

Lucie: Mange! (eat!)
Felix: I'm mangeing!

Lucie: Devine ce qu'on a pour le dessert, ça commence par un F. Ffffrrr... (guess what we are having for desert, it starts with an F)
Felix: Strawberries! (in French: Fraises)
title: June 5
